title: Seven Worlds, One Planet: How composers created breathtaking score
text:
Seven Worlds, One Planet: How composers created the epic score to those breathtaking Antarctica scenes

Seven Worlds, One Planet: How composers created the epic score to those breathtaking Antarctica scenes

Sir David Attenborough-led Seven Worlds, One Planet has launched Antarctica into our living rooms and our Sunday night’s just might never be the same again.

But the visuals have been made all the more impressive with the show’s stellar soundtrack, with a team led by legendary composer Hans Zimmer and a theme song performed by Sia.

Jacob Shea, the lead composer for the series with Bleeding Fingers Music, has now spoken to Metro.co.uk about the intricate details behind the key scenes of the first episode, and just what it takes to make the show as much of a cinematic masterpiece as it is.

‘It was a bit of a challenge because the directors wanted everything to feel vibrant and for each continent to each have their specific flavour,’ Jacob told us.

‘But at the same time they wanted it to feel like a cohesive soundtrack, and so, a lot of what I wound up doing in order to achieve that was to play into registers.’

‘In Antarctica, for instance, everything sounds shimmering and icy, and at points there’s just a violin octet playing instead of a huge string section to keep it brisk,’ he added.

‘There are a couple of themes that we came up with between me and Hans [Zimmer], which was a reoccurring and heart of the series, and we came back to that in each episode.’

‘The directors didn’t really want to do “You’re in South America, let’s hear panpipes” and things that are, not offensive, but reducing the culture to an instrument,’ Jacob explained. ‘The whole point of the series was to celebrate how diverse each continent can be.’

Here are just some of the things that you might have missed in the soundtrack to Antarctica…

Silence was golden in a fierce head-to-head between predator and prey (Picture: BBC)

Gentoo Penguins Race For Life

Sometimes music can be a hindrance to a piece rather than prove to help – and Jacob told us there was one moment in particular where he stripped back the instruments to prove that silence can sometimes be golden.

This was the case for the one scene, where viewers barely have time for breath as they follow the chase of a pack of Gentoo penguins by not one, but two predators back to back. Successfully evading Orca whales, things get even worse when they’re stranded on melted ice, with seals waiting to pounce.

‘There’s some moments where we were toying around with how big or how small to get,’ Jacob said, before elaborating, ‘Like the stand-off between a penguin and the leopard seal.

‘There’s a moment I desperately wanted to not go over the top with it. I did something subtle and played to the uncertainty and tension instead of a stand-off.

‘It really was a case of less is more, and we really pared it back to a significant degree. It usually commands a huge, climactic ending. We did the opposite.’

It took the filmmakers seven weeks to capture this phenomenon on camera (Picture: BBC)

The Whale Bubble-Net Phenomenon

One of the most stunning pieces from the show was the moment the team managed to capture from above a rarely captured behaviour from Humpback Whales – bubble-net feeding.

It was something that took seven weeks to captures by the filming team, but the results were clearly worth it.

In fact, it was this scene in particular that had a massive impact in the creation of the show’s main themes.

‘It’s kind of beyond, like when I saw it, I didn’t know that so many whales could congregate in one area, and it blew me away,’ Jacob explained. ‘Musically, it was about celebrating the spectacle of it, and I can’t imagine what it must’ve felt like to finally capture something you’ve been waiting and invested so much energy on, nearly missing it and finally getting it.

‘I just took my cue from imagining that kind of release and exhilaration. It’s a beautiful scene and it’s never been captured like that.’

‘It really felt like a moment that the themes Hans and I wrote, it felt appropriate to have that kind of scale,’ he continued. ‘The sweep gets to a giant place in terms of its orchestration. The spectacle and the size of the main theme that Hans and I composed, and it really was a case of going back to that piece and reshaping it and composing it to match that on screen.

‘It was one of those happy accidents. I sent a rough idea of the theme against the images and [the director] thought it was perfect. It worked, and then we just had to tailor it to make it as epic as possible.’

The baby albatrosses fight for acceptance was heartbreaking (Picture: BBC)

Baby Albatross fights to be accepted by its father

‘That was gut-wrenching!’ Jacob said. ‘I think I spent a week on that scene writing it because it’s such a heartbreaking story, but also beautiful because it pulls all these themes about what our effect on the world is to these creatures that aren’t within eyesight.’

‘It was an emotional exercise to write that,’ he continued.

‘It seemed to be the simpler, the better, so a lot of the score is piano and a bit of strings, but it’s primarily just a kind of a soloistic piece, and that lends towards the singular story we were working on. It brought it into focus.

‘I didn’t mean to use that, it was a trial and error exercise about what feels right about the scene.’

‘I didn’t want to overblow it to a place where it felt melodramatic,’ Joshua added. ‘That was really where I started out from.’

‘The story is so heart-wrenching, that I ultimately decided to stay out of the way.

‘It’s haunting in how powerful it is.’

The four-tonne elephant bull seals were caught in a fight for dominency (Picture: BBC)

Elephant Bull Showdown

Advertisement

One of the most brutal moments of the episode comes when an elephant seal tries to attack another, alpha seal, in a bid to overthrow him.

In a scene that knocked over cameras as the four-tonne animals went after one another, the pair were seen literally tearing chunks off the other in a bid for the territory – and the 60 females that come with it for fertilisation.

It was this creature that had previously nearly knocked over and potentially killed Sir David, who had his own experiences on the beach with the animals.

‘It’s kind of awe-inspiring, the commitment to tell these stories. So the fight was about capturing an intensity. There’s a harem, and the stakes are high,’ Jacob explained.

‘So it was really just teasing it out kind of. If you could be in one of those bull’s minds and emote what it would be like to have to protect their territory at that scale was incredible.

‘So that’s what I kept in the back of my mind. Keeping that intensity at a fever pitch no matter what.’

Seven Worlds, One Planet airs 6.15pm on BBC One.
